Package mz

Class MergeInsertion

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Merge
mz.MergeInsertion
All Implemented Interfaces:

Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroMergeInsertion
public class MergeInsertion extends Merge implements InsertionInterface<Comparable>
Merge Insertion Sort or the Ford–Johnson algorithm is a comparison sorting algorithm. It uses fewer comparisons in the worst case than the best previously known algorithms, insertion sort and merge sort, it remains of theoretical interest in connection with the problem of sorting with a minimum number of comparisons.

1.0

  • Field Details

    • MERGE_THRESHOLD

      protected int MERGE_THRESHOLD
      The threshold value for when to switch from merge sort to insertion sort. This value determines the size of subarrays below which insertion sort will be used instead of merge sort.

  • Constructor Details

    • MergeInsertion

      public MergeInsertion()
      Merge Insertion Sort:
      Merge Insertion Sort or the Ford–Johnson algorithm is a comparison sorting algorithm. It uses fewer comparisons in the worst case than the best previously known algorithms, insertion sort and merge sort, it remains of theoretical interest in connection with the problem of sorting with a minimum number of comparisons.

      Example:
      1. Group the elements pairs of (n / 2) elements, arbitrarily, leaving one element unpaired if there is an odd number of elements.
      2. Perform (n / 2) comparisons, one per pair, to determine the larger of the two elements in each pair.
      3. Recursively sort the (n / 2) larger elements from each pair, creating a sorted sequence selected of (n / 2) of the input elements.
      4. Insert at the start of selected the element that was paired with the first and smallest element of selected.
      5. Insert the remaining ((n / 2) - 1) elements of selected one at a time, with a specially chosen insertion ordering described below. Use binary search in subsequences of selected (as described below) to determine the position at which each element should be inserted.
      Note:
      The algorithm is designed to take advantage of the fact that the binary searches used to insert elements into selected are most efficient (from the point of view of worst case analysis) when the length of the subsequence that is searched is one less than a power of two.

      This is because, for those lengths, all outcomes of the search use the same number of comparisons as each other. To choose an insertion ordering that produces these lengths, consider the sorted sequence selected after step 4 of the outline above (before inserting the remaining elements).

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQMergeInsertion
      • IntroMergeInsertion

    • mergeInsertionInc

      protected void mergeInsertionInc(Comparable[] array)
      mergeInsertionInc is a modified version of the Merge Sort algorithm that incorporates an insertion sort optimization. It sorts an array of Comparable objects by recursively dividing it into smaller subarrays and performing either an insertion sort or a merge sort, depending on the size of the subarray.
      • it first checks if the left index is less than the right index. If this condition is false, it means the subarray contains only one element or is empty, so no sorting operation is needed.
      • If the condition in step 1 is true, it checks if the size of the subarray (right - left) is less than or equal to the MERGE_THRESHOLD value. If it is, it performs an insertion sort on that subarray by calling the insertionInc method.
      • If the size of the subarray is greater than the MERGE_THRESHOLD, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm. It calculates the mid index as (left + (right - left) / 2) and recursively calls mergeInsertionInc on the left and right halves of the subarray.
      • Finally, it calls the mergingInc method to merge the two sorted halves of the subarray.
      By using the insertion sort optimization for small subarrays, the algorithm aims to improve the performance of merge sort when dealing with smaller chunks of data. Insertion sort is generally more efficient than merge sort for small arrays, as it has a lower constant factor and performs fewer comparisons and swaps.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • InsertionInterface.insertionInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • MergeInterface.mergingInc(Comparable[], int, int, int)

    • mergeInsertionDec

      protected void mergeInsertionDec(Comparable[] array)
      mergeInsertionDec is a modified version of the Merge Sort algorithm that incorporates an insertion sort optimization. It sorts an array of Comparable objects by recursively dividing it into smaller subarrays and performing either an insertion sort or a merge sort, depending on the size of the subarray.
      • it first checks if the left index is less than the right index. If this condition is false, it means the subarray contains only one element or is empty, so no sorting operation is needed.
      • If the condition in step 1 is true, it checks if the size of the subarray (right - left) is less than or equal to the MERGE_THRESHOLD value. If it is, it performs an insertion sort on that subarray by calling the insertionDec method.
      • If the size of the subarray is greater than the MERGE_THRESHOLD, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm. It calculates the mid index as (left + (right - left) / 2) and recursively calls mergeInsertionDec on the left and right halves of the subarray.
      • Finally, it calls the mergingDec method to merge the two sorted halves of the subarray.
      By using the insertion sort optimization for small subarrays, the algorithm aims to improve the performance of merge sort when dealing with smaller chunks of data.     • mergeInsertionInc

      protected void mergeInsertionInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      mergeInsertionInc is a modified version of the Merge Sort algorithm that incorporates an insertion sort optimization. It sorts an array of Comparable objects by recursively dividing it into smaller subarrays and performing either an insertion sort or a merge sort, depending on the size of the subarray.
      • it first checks if the left index is less than the right index. If this condition is false, it means the subarray contains only one element or is empty, so no sorting operation is needed.
      • If the condition in step 1 is true, it checks if the size of the subarray (right - left) is less than or equal to the MERGE_THRESHOLD value. If it is, it performs an insertion sort on that subarray by calling the insertionInc method.
      • If the size of the subarray is greater than the MERGE_THRESHOLD, it proceeds with the merge sort algorithm. It calculates the mid index as (left + (right - left) / 2) and recursively calls mergeInsertionInc on the left and right halves of the subarray.
      • Finally, it calls the mergingInc method to merge the two sorted halves of the subarray.
      By using the insertion sort optimization for small subarrays, the algorithm aims to improve the performance of merge sort when dealing with smaller chunks of data. Insertion sort is generally more efficient than merge sort for small arrays, as it has a lower constant factor and performs fewer comparisons and swaps.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (exclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • InsertionInterface.insertionInc(Comparable[], int, int)
